issue.name: Accuracy
issue.definition: The target text does not accurately reflect the source text, allowing for any differences authorized by specifications.

notes.note: Most cases of //accuracy// are addressed by one of the more specific subtypes listed below.
In Machine Translation literature, this category is typically referred to as “Adequacy”.

issue.name: Addition
issue.definition: The target text includes text not present in the source.

examples.example: A translation includes portions of another translation that were inadvertently pasted into the document.

issue.name: Grammatical register
issue.definition: The content uses the wrong grammatical register, such as using informal pronouns or verb forms when their formal counterparts are required.

notes.note: For cases of general stylistic formality that do not involve the incorrect use of grammatical markers of formality, //register// should be used instead.

examples.example: A text used for a highly formal announcement uses the Norwegian du form instead of the expected De.

issue.name: Mistranslation
issue.definition: The target content does not accurately represent the source content.

examples.example: A source text states that a medicine should not be administered in doses greater than 200 mg, but the translation states that it should be administered in doses greater than 200 mg (i.e., negation has been omitted).

issue.name: Ambiguous translation
issue.definition: An unambiguous source text is translated ambiguously

notes.note: This issue is distinct from //ambiguity// in that it is limited to issues where the translation process has introduced the ambiguity.

examples.example: A text that means that someone is highly recommended is translated as “I cannot recommend this too highly.” (The meaning can be that the speaker cannot make a good recommendation or that it is highly recommended.)

issue.name: Date/time
issue.definition: Dates or times do not match between source and target.

examples.example: A German source text provides the date 09.02.09 (=February 9, 2009) but the English target renders it as September 2, 2009.
An English source text specifies a time of “4:40 PM” but this is rendered as 04:40 (=4:40 AM) in a German translation.

issue.name: Entity (such as name or place
issue.definition: Names, places, or other “named entities” do not match

examples.example: The source text refers to Dublin, Ohio, but the target incorrectly refers to Dublin, Ireland.

issue.name: False friend
issue.definition: The translation has incorrectly used a word that is superficially similar to the source word.

examples.example: The Italian word simpatico has been translated as sympathetic in English.

issue.name: Improper exact TM match
issue.definition: An translation is provided as an exact match from a translation memory (TM) system, but is actually incorrect.

notes.note: This issue type applies only in cases where TM technology is used.

examples.example: A TM system returns “Press the Start button” as an exact (100%) match, when the proper translation should be “Press the Begin button”.

issue.name: Should not have been translated
issue.definition: Text was translated that should have been left untranslated

examples.example: A Japanese translation refers to “Apple Computers” as アップルコンピュータ when the English expression should have been left untranslated.

issue.name: Number
issue.definition: Numbers are inconsistent between source and target.

examples.example: The source text specifies that a part is 124 mm long but the target text specifies that it is 135 mm long.

issue.name: Over-translation
issue.definition: The target text is more specific than the source text

notes.note: In some cases differences in concept structure between languages may render an apparent over-translation necessary. In such cases this issue should not be considered an error, although the issue may be noted for further consideration.

examples.example: The source text refers to a “boy” but is translated with a word that applies only to young boys rather than the more general term

issue.name: Overly literal
issue.definition: The translation is overly literal.

examples.example: A Hungarian text contains the phrase Tele van a hocipőd?, which has been translated as “Are your snow boots full?” rather than with the idiomatic meaning of “Feeling overwhelmed?”.

issue.name: Mistranslation of technical relationship
issue.definition: Content decribing the relationship(s) within a technical description is translated inaccurately with respect to technical knowledge (even if the translation otherwise appears plausible).

notes.note: This issue is not used for incorrect use of individual terms, which would be classified in //terminology// or one of its children. Rather, it is used for cases where a translation might appear to be correct but where it ends up misconveying information about a technical subject.
Instances of this issue may point to confusing source materials or to lack of translator experience in a specialized domain.

examples.example: A physics text describes the interaction of subatomic particles in a medical scanning device. The translation seems plausible, but incorrectly conveys the relationship of two particles and is therefore incorrect.

A source text describes how a piano action (the mechanism connecting a piano key to the hammer that strikes a string) is translated in a way that incorrectly conveys the relationship between two components.

issue.name: Unit conversion
issue.definition: The target text has not converted numeric values as needed to adjust for different units (e.g., currencies, metric vs. U.S. measurement systems).

examples.example: A source text specifies that an item is 25 centimeters (~10 inches) long, but the source states that it is 25 inches (63.5 cm) long.

issue.name: Omission
issue.definition: Content is missing from the translation that is present in the source.

examples.example: A paragraph present in the source is missing in the translation

issue.name: Omitted variable
issue.definition: A variable placeholder is omitted from a translated text

examples.example: A translated text should read “Number of lives remaining: $lifeNumber” but is rendered as “Number of lives remaining:”, with the variable $lifeNumber omitted

issue.name: Under-translation
issue.definition: The target text is less specific than the source text

notes.note: In some cases differences in concept structure between languages may render an apparent under-translation necessary. In such cases this issue should not be considered an error, although the issue may be noted for further consideration.

examples.example: The source text uses words that refer to a specific type of miltary officer but the target text refers to military officers in general

issue.name: Untranslated
issue.definition: Content that should have been translated has been left untranslated.

examples.example: A sentence in a Japanese document translated into English is left in Japanese.

issue.name: Untranslated graphic
issue.definition: Text in a graphic was left untranslated.

examples.example: Part labels in a graphic were left untranslated even though running text was translated

issue.name: Design
issue.definition: There is a problem relating to design aspects (vs. linguistic aspects) of the content.

notes.note: Design issues may exist either in documentions in isolation (e.g., a second-level heading is formatted as a first-level heading) or in relationship between source and target (e.g., headings are formatted differently between source and target).

examples.example: A document is formatted incorrectly

issue.name: Graphics and tables
issue.definition: Issues related to the formatting of graphics and tables.

examples.example: A graphic is garbled and the wrong version is shown

issue.name: Call-outs and captions
issue.definition: There are issues with call-outs (text within a graphic that identifies parts) or captions.

examples.example: During localization the location of numbers used for call-outs has been shifted and the call-outs are no longer usable.

issue.name: Missing graphic/table
issue.definition: A graphic or table is missing.

examples.example: An HTML file is missing an tag, so no graphic is shown.

issue.name: Position of graphic/table
issue.definition: A graphic or table is positioned incorrectly.

examples.example: A text refers to Figure 1, but Figure 1 appears six pages after the point where it was referred to.

issue.name: Hyphenation
issue.definition: Text in a layed-out format is hyphenated incorrectly

examples.example: A word processor has been set to use German hyphenation for a Hungarian text. As a result the word mennyi is hyphenated as men-nyi instead of the correct meny-nyi.

issue.name: Length
issue.definition: There is a significant discrepancy between the source and the target text lengths.

examples.example: An English sentence is 253 characters long but its German translation is 51 characters long.

issue.name: Local formatting
issue.definition: Issues related to local formatting (rather than to overall layout concerns)
issue.examples: A portion of the text displays a (non-systematic) formatting problem (e.g., a single heading is formatted incorrectly, even though other headings appear properly).

issue.name: Font
issue.definition: Issues related to local font usage (i.e., font choices that impact a span of content rather than the global choice of the document).

examples.example: Warning texts are set in sans-serif, but one of them appears in a serif font.
A portion of Japanese text is set with an obliqued face (corresponding to italics in the source text) when dot accents should have been used with a non-oblique face.

issue.name: Bold/italic
issue.definition: Bold or italics are used incorrectly.

examples.example: A book title should have been italicized, but the italics were omitted.

issue.name: Font, single/double-width (CJK only)
issue.definition: Single-width characters are used when double-width are intended, or vice versa.

examples.example: A Japanese text includes カタカナ (full-width kana) when specifications required ｶﾀｶﾅ (half-width kana) instead, due to a limited display size.

issue.name: Wrong size
issue.definition: The font size is incorrect

examples.example: A legal notice should be set in a 9 pt size, but was instead set in 7 pt.

issue.name: Kerning
issue.definition: Kerning (inter-character spacing) is wrong.

examples.example: The letters T and A in the word TAMPA are spaced too close together and collide.

issue.name: Leading
issue.definition: Leading (spacing between lines of text) is off

examples.example: A translated Japanese text has set lines too close together, making the text difficult to read.

issue.name: Paragraph indentation
issue.definition: A paragraph is indented improperly.

examples.example: The first line of body paragraphs should be indented 4 mm, but some paragraphs were indented 25 mm instead.

issue.name: Text alignment
issue.definition: A portion of a text is aligned inappropriately.

examples.example: A heading should be left-aligned but was centered instead.

issue.name: Markup
issue.definition: Issues related to “markup” (codes used to represent structure or formatting of text, also known as “tags”).

examples.example: Markup is used incorrectly, resulting in incorrect formatting.

issue.name: Added markup
issue.definition: The target text has markup added with no corresponding markup in the source.

examples.example: A source segment has no formatting tags, but the target has a set of italic tags.

issue.name: Inconsistent markup
issue.definition: Markup elements are inconsistent between the source and target

examples.example: A target text has a set of tags for bold face in the same location where the source has tags for italics.

issue.name: Misplaced markup
issue.definition: Markup is present but misplaced.

examples.example: A segment has three sets of paired formatting tags at the end, after the final full stop (.).

issue.name: Missing markup
issue.definition: Markup in the source is missing in the target.

examples.example: A source segment has a set of italic tags, but the target text does not have any tags.

issue.name: Questionable markup
issue.definition: Markup is present that appears malformed or inappropriate for its context.

examples.example: A text has opening tags but no closing tags for formatting.

issue.name: Missing text
issue.definition: Existing text is missing in the final laid-out version

notes.note: This issue does not refer to omitted text (i.e., text that was present in the source but not present in the translation). Instead it refers only to cases where text is present in some form but does not appear in the laid-out version. It also does not refer to text that has been truncated due to text expansion.

examples.example: A translation is complete, but during DTP a text box was inadvertently moved off the page and so the translated text does not appear in a rendered PDF version.

issue.name: Overall design (layout
issue.definition: Issues related to overall layout and design (versus local formatting)

examples.example: A document is formatted incorrectly (e.g., it should have been set up for a print layout but instead is set up for an online presentation.

issue.name: Color
issue.definition: Colors are used incorrectly

examples.example: Headings should be blue but are green instead.

issue.name: Footnote/endnote format
issue.definition: Footnotes or endnotes are placed inappropriately or use incorrect in-text symbols

examples.example: Specifications state that endnotes should be used with roman numerals but footnotes were used with in-text symbols (*, †, ‡, etc.).

issue.name: Global font choice
issue.definition: The overall font chosen is incorrect or inappropriate.

notes.note: While this issue may apply to both source and target, it is most likely to apply to the target.

examples.example: A English source text uses a normal-weight serif font for body text but the Japanese translation uses a heavy-weight “gothic” (roughly, sans-serif) font appropriate for headlines only.

issue.name: Headers and footers
issue.definition: Headers or footers are formatted incorrectly

examples.example: Headers should appear on every page but have been omitted on odd-numbered pages.

issue.name: Margins
issue.definition: Text margins are incorrect.

examples.example: Specifications called for 4 cm inside margins, but 2.5 cm margins were used instead.

issue.name: Page breaks
issue.definition: Page breaks appear in inappropriate locations.

examples.example: There is a page break between a figure and its caption.

issue.name: Widows/orphans
issue.definition: The text has widows or orphans (single or short lines of text that appear on a separate page from the rest of a paragraph).

examples.example: Specifications state that at least two lines of a paragraph must appear on a page (if the paragraph is more than one line), but a single line starts a page while two appear on the previous page.

issue.name: Truncation/text expansion
issue.definition: The target text has insufficient room to display the translated text according to specifications.

notes.note: This issue may indicate an underlying //internationalization// problem.

examples.example: The German translation of an English string in a user interface runs off the edge of a dialogue box and cannot be read.

issue.name: Fluency
issue.definition: Issues related to the form or content of a text, irrespective as to whether it is a translation or not.

notes.note: If an issue can be detected only by comparing the source and target, it MUST NOT be categorized as //fluency// or any of its children.

examples.example: A text has errors in it that prevent it from being understood.

issue.name: Ambiguity
issue.definition: The text is ambiguous in its meaning.

notes.note: This issue is distinguished from //ambiguous-translation// by its focus on monolingual ambiguity. In cases where the translation process has introduced ambiguity, //ambiguous-translation// should be used instead, if it is included in a metric. However, any ambiguity in a source text would be classified under this issue.

examples.example: A text reads “I cannot recommend this too highly.” (The meaning can be that the speaker cannot make a good recommendation or that it is highly recommended.)

issue.name: Unclear reference
issue.definition: The text uses relative pronouns or other referential mechanisms that are unclear as to their reference.

examples.example: A text reads “After completing this, move to the next step,” but there are a number of possible referents for this in the text.

issue.name: Link/cross-reference
issue.definition: A link or cross reference points to an incorrect or nonexistent location

examples.example: An HTML document has an href that points to a file that does not exist.

issue.name: Document-external link
issue.definition: A link or cross reference points to an incorrect or nonexistent location outside of the same document within which it occurs

examples.example: A link in an HTML document points to a U.S. government URL that has moved and no longer exists.

issue.name: Document-internal link
issue.definition: A link or cross reference points to an incorrect or nonexistent location within the same document within which it occurs.

examples.example: An internal link refers to the location “#section5” but there is no anchor “section5” in the document.

issue.name: Character encoding
issue.definition: Characters are garbled due to incorrect application of an encoding.

examples.example: A text document in UTF-8 encoding is opened as ISO Latin-1, resulting in all “upper ASCII” characters being garbled.

issue.name: Coherence
issue.definition: The text is not coherent

notes.note: Since coherence applies above the segment level, this issue type would generally be assessed with a holistic metric rather than an analytic one, although any claims that a text is not coherent should be able to point to specific portions and problems. Often these specific problems can be classified as //coherence// or //inconsistency// issues in an analytic metric.

examples.example: While individual sentences of the text are all perfectly fluent, the text as a whole does not make sense and is inconsistent with itself.

issue.name: Cohesion
issue.definition: Portions of the text needed to connect it into an understandable whole (e.g., reference, substitution, ellipsis, conjunction, and lexical cohesion) are missing or incorrect.

notes.note: Cohesion applies at the local level to incorrect or missing elements needed for the intended meaning of the text to be clear. Cohesion problems at the local level may contribute to //coherence// problems for the text as a whole.

examples.example: An English text is missing conjunctions and particles (e.g., “thus”, “therefore”, “but”, and “however”) needed for the logic of the text to be clear.

issue.name: Corpus conformance
issue.definition: The content is deemed to have a level of conformance to a reference corpus. The non-conformance type reflects the degree to which the text conforms to a reference corpus given an algorithm that combines several classes of error type to produce an aggregate rating.

notes.note: One example of this issue type might involve output from a quality estimation system that delivers a warning that a text has a very low quality estimation score.

examples.example: A text reading “The harbour connected which to printer is busy or configared not properly” is flagged by a language analysis tool as suspect based on its lack of conformance to an existing corpus.

issue.name: Duplication
issue.definition: Content has been duplicated (e.g., a word or longer portion of text is repeated unintentionally).

examples.example: A text reads “The man the man whom she saw…”
A paragraph appears verbatim twice in a row.

issue.name: Grammar
issue.definition: Issues related to the grammar or syntax of the text, other than spelling and orthography.

examples.example: An English text reads “The man was seeing the his wife.”

issue.name: Function words
issue.definition: A function word (e.g., a preposition, “helping verb”, article, determiner) is used incorrectly.

examples.example: A text reads “Check the part number as given in the screen” instead of “…on the screen”.
A text reads “The graphic is then copied into an internal memory” instead of “The graphic is copied to internal memory.”

issue.name: Word form
issue.definition: There is a problem in the form of a word

examples.example: An English text has becomed instead of became.

issue.name: Agreement
issue.definition: Two or more words do not agree with respect to case, number, person, or other grammatical features

examples.example: A text reads “They was expecting a report.”

issue.name: Part of speech
issue.definition: A word is the wrong part of speech

examples.example: A text reads “Read these instructions careful” instead of “Read these instructions carefully.”

issue.name: Tense/mood/aspect
issue.definition: A verbal form displays the wrong tense, mood, or aspect
issue.examples: An English text reads “After the button is pushing” (present progressive) instead of “After the button has been pushed” (past passive)

issue.name: Word order
issue.definition: The word order is incorrect

examples.example: A German text reads “Er hat gesehen den Mann” instead of “Er hat den Mann gesehen.”

issue.name: Inconsistency
issue.definition: The text shows internal inconsistency.

examples.example: The text states that bug reports should be submitted to a mailing list in one place and via an online bug tracker tool in another.

issue.name: Inconsistent with external reference
issue.definition: The text is inconsistent with a specified external reference

notes.note: For inconsistent terminology, options in the Terminology branch should be used instead.

examples.example: Translation specifications state that quotes in a text must match the 1957 edition of a book, but the translator used the 1943 edition, which was substantially different.

issue.name: Images vs. text
issue.definition: Phrasing/wording is inconsistent between text shown in images and running text.

examples.example: A screen shot shows a button with the text “Open other…” but the text referring to the screen shot tells the user to click on the “Open alternative…” button.

issue.name: Inconsistent abbreviations
issue.definition: The form of abbreviations is inconsistent in the text.

examples.example: A text uses both “app.” and “approx.” for approximately.

issue.name: Inconsistent link/cross-reference
issue.definition: Links are inconsistent in the text

examples.example: An HTML file contains numerous links to other HTML files; some have been updated to reflect the appropriate language version while some point to the source language version.

issue.name: Index/TOC
issue.definition: Issues related to an index or Table of Contents (TOC).

examples.example: A Table of Contents is missing items that should be included.

issue.name: Index/TOC format
issue.definition: An index/TOC is formatted incorrectly

examples.example: A Table of Content should be formatted with variable (hierarchical) indenting and tab leader characters, but is instead displayed as a “run-in” list.

issue.name: Missing/incorrect TOC item
issue.definition: Items in an index/TOC are incorrect or missing

examples.example: A chapter heading is not listed in a Table of Contents.

issue.name: Page references
issue.definition: An index/TOC refers to incorrect page numbers

examples.example: A table of contents refers to page numbers from the source document that do not apply to the translated text.

issue.name: Locale convention
issue.definition: The text does not adhere to locale-specific mechanical conventions and violates requirements for the presentation of content in the target locale.

notes.note: This issue type is distinguished from //locale-specific-content// in that this category refers only to whether the text is given the proper mechanical form for the locale, not whether the content applies to the locale or not. If text conforms to conventions for the locale, but does not apply to the target locale, //locale-specific-content// should be used instead.

examples.example: An incorrect format for currency is used for a German text, with a period (.) instead of a comma (,) as a thousands separator.

A text translated into Japanese uses Western quote marks to indicate titles rather than the appropriate Japanese quote marks (「 and 」). (Note: this example would be categorized as //quote-mark-type// if the metric includes it.)

issue.name: Address format
issue.definition: Content uses the wrong format for addresses.

notes.note: Very often this issue indicates an underlying //internationalization// problem.

examples.example: An online form translated from English to Hindi requires a street number even though many addresses in India do not include a house number.

issue.name: Postal code
issue.definition: Content uses the wrong form for postal codes.

notes.note: Very often this issue indicates an underlying //internationalization// problem.

examples.example: A translated online form validates all postal codes as consisting of exactly five numbers but the target locale uses a combination of six letters and numbers.

issue.name: Calendar type
issue.definition: Content uses the wrong type of calendar.

notes.note: Very often this issue indicates an underlying //internationalization// problem.

examples.example: A tourism text translated from Arabic English gives a year as 1435, but it should have been converted from the Islamic calendar to the Gregorian calendar year 2014.

issue.name: Culture-specific reference
issue.definition: Content inappropriately uses a culture-specific reference that will not be understandable to the intended audience

notes.note: In the cases of texts that were written with the intention that they be translated, this issue may indicate a broader conceptual or Internationalization problem.

examples.example: An English text refers to steps in a process as “First base”, “Second base”, and “Third base”, and to successful completion as a “Home run” and uses other metaphors from baseball. These prove difficult to translate and confuse the target audience in Germany.
An marketing text in Greek includes reference to popular Greek music. When translated into English these references are not understandable to the target audience.

issue.name: Currency format
issue.definition: Content uses the wrong format for currency.

notes.note: Very often this issue indicates an underlying //internationalization// problem.

examples.example: A text dealing with business transactions from English into Hindi assumes that all currencies will be expressed in simple units, while the convention in India is to give such prices in lakh rupees (10000 rupees)

issue.name: Date format
issue.definition: A text uses a date format inappropriate for its locale.

examples.example: An English text has “2012-06-07” instead of the expected “06/07/2012.”

issue.name: Locale-specific punctuation
issue.definition: The text systematically uses punctuation not appropriate for the specified locale

examples.example: A text translated from English to Japanese maintains European-style punctuation—such as full-stops (.)—instead of using the appropriate Japanese punctuation, such as the Japanese full stop (。).

issue.name: Quote mark type
issue.definition: A text uses quote marks inappropriate for its locale.

notes.note: Use this issue only if the problem is systematic. Otherwise use Typography or Punctuation, if available.

examples.example: A French text should use guillemets («») but instead systematically uses German-style quotes („”)

issue.name: Measurement format
issue.definition: A text uses a measurement format inappropriate for its locale.

examples.example: A text in France uses feet and inches and Fahrenheit temperatures.

issue.name: Name format
issue.definition: A text uses a name format inappropriate for its locale.

notes.note: Very often this issue indicates an underlying //internationalization// problem.

examples.example: A text translated from Hungarian to English presents names with the family name first when the name order should be instead inverted to have family name last.
A web form translated for Indonesia requires users to provide a “last name” even though many Indonesians have only a single name.
A translated text refers to “Pedro Diego Estavez” as “Mr. Estavez” rather than “Mr. Diego”.

issue.name: National language standard
issue.definition: A text violates national language standards.

examples.example: A French advertising text uses anglicisms that are forbidden for print texts by the Academie française specifications.

issue.name: Number format
issue.definition: A text uses a number format inappropriate for its locale.

notes.note: Very often this issue indicates an underlying //internationalization// problem.

examples.example: A German text has “123,456” instead of the locale-appropriate “123.456”.
A text translated for India has “10000” rather than “1000”.

issue.name: Shortcut key
issue.definition: A translated software product uses shortcuts that do not conform to locale expectations or that make no sense for the locale

notes.note: Very often this issue indicates an underlying //internationalization// problem.

examples.example: A software product uses CTRL-S to save a file in Hungarian, rather than the appropriate CTRL-M (for mentenni).

issue.name: Telephone format
issue.definition: Content uses the wrong form for telephone numbers

notes.note: Very often this issue indicates an underlying //internationalization// problem.

examples.example: A German text presents a telephone number in the format (xxx) xxx - xxxx instead of the expected 0xx followed by a group of digits separated into groups by spaces.

issue.name: Time format
issue.definition: A text uses a time format inappropriate for its locale.

examples.example: A text written for the U.S. uses a 24-hour time notation rather than AM/PM time.

issue.name: Nonallowed characters
issue.definition: The text includes characters that are not allowed.

examples.example: A text may not include colons or forward- or back-slashes, which might cause confusion with path names on some computer systems, but it contains these characters.

issue.name: Offensive
issue.definition: Content is offensive according to the specifications

notes.note: if offensive is to by used, clear guidelines should be given since content offensive in one context may be acceptable in another.

In many cases offensive content may be detected in a (semi)automatic fashion through the use of lists of unacceptable phrases, often in conjunction with terminology checkers. However, automatic checkers will not be able to identify all potentially offensive content, especially as content considered unobjectionable in one context or culture may be considered highly offensive in another.

examples.example: A text contains words generally considered to be profanities outside of a context where they would be allowed
Images in a document depict nudity for a culture where nudity is considered offensive
An American text uses the “OK” symbol (👌) to indicate approval, but this symbol is considered offensive in Brazil.

issue.name: Pattern problem
issue.definition: The text contains a pattern (e.g., text that matches a regular expression) that is not allowed.

examples.example: The regular expression [\"\'”’][,\\.;] (i.e., a quote mark followed by a comma, full stop, or semicolon) is defined as not allowed for a project but a text contains the string ”, (closing quote followed by a comma).

issue.name: Register
issue.definition: The text uses a level of formality higher or lower than required by the specifications or general language conventions.

notes.note: Register involves a number of factors, including appropriateness of the discourse for the specific subject field, the level of formality, and the mode of discourse (e.g., written text versus transcribed speech).
The notion of register used in this document is derived from Systemic Functional Linguistics.
For uses of the improper grammatical register that do not otherwise impact style, such as German du vs. Sie, use //grammatical-register// instead.

examples.example: A formal letter uses contractions, colloquialisms, and expressions characteristic of spoken rather than written language, and those comes across as less serious than intended.

issue.name: Variants/slang
issue.definition: The text uses words such as slang that are inappropriate for the intended register.

examples.example: A refers to dollars as “clams” in a case when this slang term would be inappropriate.

issue.name: Sorting
issue.definition: A list is not in the appropriately collated sequence.

examples.example: A listing of items should be in alphabetical order but appears in a random order instead.

issue.name: Spelling
issue.definition: Issues related to spelling of words

examples.example: The German word Zustellung is spelled Zustetlugn.

issue.name: Capitalization
issue.definition: Issues related to capitalization

examples.example: The name John Smith is written as “john smith”

issue.name: Diacritics
issue.definition: Issues related to the use of diacritics

examples.example: The Hungarian word bőven (using o with a double acute (˝)) is spelled as bõven, using a tilde (˜), which is not found in Hungarian.

issue.name: Typography
issue.definition: Issues related to the mechanical presentation of text. This category should be used for any typographical errors other than spelling.

notes.note: Do not use for issues related to //spelling//.

examples.example: A text uses punctuation incorrectly.
A text has an extraneous hard return in the middle of a paragraph.

issue.name: Punctuation
issue.definition: Punctuation is used incorrectly (for the locale or style)

notes.note: In most cases it is not necessary to distinguish this issue type from //typography//.

examples.example: An English text uses a semicolon where a comma should be used.

issue.name: Unpaired quote marks or brackets
issue.definition: One of a pair of quotes or brackets—e.g., a (, ) [, ], {, or } character—is missing from text.

examples.example: A text reads “King Ludwig of Bavaria (1845–1896 was deposed on account of his supposed madness,” omitting the closing parenthesis around the dates.

issue.name: Whitespace
issue.definition: Whitespace is used incorrectly

examples.example: A document uses a string of space characters instead of tabs
Extra spaces are added at the start of a string

issue.name: Unintelligible
issue.definition: The exact nature of the error cannot be determined. Indicates a major break down in fluency.

examples.example: The following text appears in an English translation of a German automotive manual: “The brake from whe this કુતારો િસ S149235 part numbr,,.”
Text appears in a translation that cannot be understood at all.

issue.name: Functional
issue.definition: Functional errors introduced by lack of support for languages, scripts, or other locale-specific features

notes.note: If child issues are included, most issues in this category would be assigned to them.

examples.example: The French version of a software package fails to function as expected because it was engineered with assumptions based on American English.

issue.name: Case folding
issue.definition: Text casing routines do not support needed languages

notes.note: This issue may also impact //text-indexing// and //string-matching// if case-insensitive indexing or matching is used.

examples.example: In Turkish the upper-case form of i is İ and the lower-case form of I is ı. As a result case-changing algorithms that are not internationalized and aware of Turkish will change the case of these characters incorrectly.

issue.name: Character set support
issue.definition: Software does not support character sets needed for specific locales

examples.example: A database application cannot process or produce text stored in ISO Latin 6 (Nordic) encoding and so cannot interface with needed legacy systems in Norway.

issue.name: Fixed collation
issue.definition: A collation (text sorting) routine does not support locale-specific collation sequences

notes.note: Specific results of this problem will often be classified under //sorting//.

examples.example: The sort routine in a spreadsheet does a simple sort by Unicode code-point sequence, and does not support needed collation sequences for various markets.

issue.name: Hard-coded keyboard command
issue.definition: Key-board shortcuts or other commands are hard-coded into the system and do not function when alternative keyboards are selected

examples.example: A vital keyboard in the English version command involves pressing the A key, but when the program is run using a Russian keyboard layout, it is unusable because the program is waiting U#0041 (A) for instead of U#0391 (А).

issue.name: Input validation
issue.definition: Validation of input does not function properly because it assumes certain parameters that do not apply in all locales

examples.example: A form validates names against a regular expression, [A-Za-z\']+, but fails when a Japanese user enters a name that does includes characters other than standard Roman characters

issue.name: Missing fall-back text
issue.definition: A program includes a “fall-back” language for content that has not been localized, but the needed fall-back text is missing.

notes.note: It is common practice to allow software or websites to fall back on another language if some content is missing. For example, a partially-localized German website might display some content in English for pages that have not yet been localized.

examples.example: A French-language website has not been fully localized. When the user clicks a link to one of these pages he or she should be taken to the English-language source page, but instead is taken to a blank page with no content.

issue.name: String matching
issue.definition: String-matching routines do not properly consider language-specific rules

notes.note: This issue may also extend to Unicode characters using different normalization forms if a matching algorthim does not consider canonical equivalence. This issue is closely related to //text-indexing//

examples.example: A German matching algorithm should recognize that the names Roemer and Römer are the same name (oe and ö are alternative spelling for the same sound) but does not, thus returning only some of the appropriate matches to a query.

issue.name: Text corruption
issue.definition: Text entered into a system is corrupted

notes.note: Problems with text corruption often emerge when different systems interact with each other without considering the encoding emitted or expected by other systems.

examples.example: When users enter text with accented vowels using UTF-8 encoding, these are systematically converted to other characters due to an internal text-processing routine that assumes ISO Latin-1 encoding.

issue.name: Text indexing
issue.definition: When text is indexed for retrieval and processing, the indexing does not account for language-specific requirements.

notes.note: This issue is closely related to //string-matching//

examples.example: The German name Römer should be indexed for retrieval as “Römer”, “Roemer”, and “Romer”, but the indexing engine uses only the first. As a result, users looking for this name in a database will not find it if they use one of the alternative forms.

issue.name: Time zone support
issue.definition: Software does not support multiple time zones or conversions between time zones

examples.example: A shared calendar system does not consider timezones and sends out all notifications based on the time on the server’s clock. As a result it does not send out reminders for meetings at the appropriate time.

issue.name: Writing system support
issue.definition: A needed writing system is not fully supported

examples.example: A system is localized for China, but required support for the writing systems of Chinese minority languages is not usable.

issue.name: Bi-di support
issue.definition: The software cannot support bi-directional scripts, such as Arabic and Hebrew

examples.example: Text in Arabic is displayed left-to-right rather than right-to-left.

issue.name: Font rendering engine
issue.definition: Fonts for one or more scripts are not rendered properly

notes.note: Font-rendering problems are extremely common in software that has not previously been adapted to support “complex” scripts.

examples.example: Arabic text entered into a system does not display appropriate contextual variations (ligatures) and instead uses only medial character forms, rendering the result unreadable.

issue.name: Keyboard support
issue.definition: Software does not provide support for appropriate local-language keyboards

examples.example: A computer program provides support only for American English keyboards and so does not work properly in Icelandic since users cannot enter text with Icelandic-specific characters.

issue.name: Internationalization
issue.definition: There is a problem related to the internationalization of content.

notes.note: While //internationaliztion// errors are generally detected in the target content, they refer to problems in the source that cause problems with translated/localized content. Even in cases where //internationalization// is not being specifically checked, if problems related to internationalization are encountered, they should generally be reported to the content creators.
As of August 2014, the intention is to expand this branch in the future with more specific issue types.

examples.example: A document assumes that all addresses use postal codes conforming to the U.S. “zip+four” convention and includes a verification step for postal codes that does not allow for non-U.S. codes.
A computer program is localized but some content remains untranslated because it was embedded in the program code and not made accessible to the translator.

issue.name: Concatenation
issue.definition: Text is concatenated in ways that will not function properly when the text is translated

examples.example: A localizable string contains the following: \"You have found the \".$item.\". Do you wish to pick it up?\". When translated this string will cause problems because the article before the item and the equivalent of “it” will both need to be changed to reflect the content of the variable $item.

issue.name: Confusable security
issue.definition: Software does not provide any security protection against easily confusable character such as Latin-script A, Greek Α, and Cyrillic А, thus allowing users to impersonate other users’ names.

notes.note: This issue has emerged with the advent of pervasive Unicode support that allows multiple scripts to be combined in input. Solving this problem requires careful parsing of input.

examples.example: Users can select user names with any valid, non-control Unicode characters. As a result a user creates the user name Тоny (with the first two letters in Cyrillic) to impersonate an administrative user with the name Tony (all in Latin script).

issue.name: Embedded string
issue.definition: Textual content is embedded in other elements in ways that make it inaccessible during the localization process.

notes.note: The subtypes of this issue comprise the most common examples.

examples.example: The UI of an industrial system includes graphical images of text that cannot be edited as text.

issue.name: Embedded string in code
issue.definition: String references are embedded in computer code rather than externalized to resource files. As a result the string content is accessible only by manipulatin the source code of the application.

examples.example: Error messages for a product are stored as variables directly in the source code of a software product and are therefore not localized when UI strings are sent for translation.

issue.name: Embedded string in graphic
issue.definition: A graphics contains embedded text as an image that cannot be edited

notes.note: Solving this problem generally requires access to original application files used to produce graphics initially rather than to rendered down-stream versions use for web display, display in software UIs, or embedding in word-processing applications.

examples.example: A service manual contains an image of a mechanical system with part labels stored in the “flattened” graphic. As a result the localization process cannot produce localized versions of the graphic

issue.name: Graphical aspects
issue.definition: Graphical aspects of the content cannot be easily changed to match locale-specific expectations.

notes.note: This issue and its children apply only to cases where cultural aspects of graphics are not accessible to the localization process and so cannot be adapted.

examples.example: A piece of software being localized for the Swedish market contain images of products available only in the U.S. market.

issue.name: Color internationalization
issue.definition: Use of colors is fixed and not adaptable to other locales

notes.note: This issue type does not apply merely to the use of culture-specific colors, but rather to cases where the colors are not made accessible to the localization process and so cannot be changed.

examples.example: A UK-based website uses a red, white, and blue color scheme and hard-codes these colors into graphical assets and inline styles. When translated for China, these colors are inappropriate but cannot be changed because of the way they are encoded into the site.

issue.name: Culture-specific graphic
issue.definition: Graphics embed cultural assumptions or references and cannot be changed

notes.note: If graphics can be easily changed in the localization process, this issue does not apply.

examples.example: A graphic depicts a “road trip” by showing sights familiar to a German audience that would be unknown in other locales.

issue.name: Hard-coded graphic
issue.definition: Computer code contains “hard-coded” graphics that cannot be accessed or changed during the localization process.

examples.example: A website uses inline base64-encoded representations of some graphics to speed up load times for the page, but these graphics are thus not accessible for localization.

issue.name: Language-dependent logic
issue.definition: Content includes language- or locale-dependent logical assumptions that prevent it from being appropriately localized

notes.note: This issue type is common when going between European and Asian markets. In some cases texts that are perfectly clear in one market may be difficult to follow in another due to culture-specific differences in logic.

examples.example: A technical text uses a “deductive” reasoning style that cannot be easily adapted to areas expecting an “inductive” reasoning style.

issue.name: Language-specific tool support
issue.definition: Needed tools that specifically support required languages are missing or do not function as expected

examples.example: A word processor is released for Kazakhstan but does not contain tools needed to fully support the Kazakh language.

issue.name: Grammar checker
issue.definition: A needed grammar checking is missing or does not support the required language.

examples.example: The grammar checker in a word processor sold in Germany supports English only.

issue.name: Hyphenator
issue.definition: A hyphenation engine does not support a needed language

examples.example: A desk-top publishing (DTP) tool has a hyphenation engine that does not support Hungarian.

issue.name: Spell checker
issue.definition: A spell checker does not support a needed language

examples.example: The spell-checking engine used in a presentation tool localized for Korean does not include rules for the Korean language and cannot be used to spell-check Korean text.

issue.name: Localization support
issue.definition: Aspects of how a software product presents locale-sensitive data are not properly internationalized

notes.note: See the subtypes for specific examples. Note that this issue type and its children apply to internationaliztion problems in the source, not to specific instances in a target language, although they may be discovered as problems classified under //locale-convention// in specific target languages. Although most of the examples of child nodes use specific instances where problems appear, they all refer to engineering problems of the source content.

examples.example: An online submission form to register for appointments with a product demonstrator does not allow data to be submitted for many countries because it validates data against a US-centric model.

issue.name: Address internationalization
issue.definition: An inport form, database, or other software component does not properly support international address formats

notes.note: Corresponds to //address-format// in //locale-convention//.
This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: A form enforces a US model of street addresses that does not apply in many target languages and does not support notation of districts or other important features of addresses in some countries.

issue.name: Calendar internationalization
issue.definition: Software does not support one or more calendar types needed for some locales.

notes.note: This issue does not apply to cases where dates are displayed in the wrong format, but according to the right calendar system.
Corresponds to //calendar-format// in //locale-convention//.
This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: A task-management system designed in the U.S. displays Sunday as the first day of the week, while many countries list it as the last day of the week.
A website displays all dates according to the Gregorian calendar, but the target audience in much of the Middle East prefers to use the Islamic calendar.

issue.name: Currency internationalization
issue.definition: A system does not support multiple currencies or specific currencies needed for individual markets

notes.note: Corresponds to //currency-format// in //locale-convention//. This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: An online commerce form displays all amounts in euros, but customers use the form in countries that use other currencies.

issue.name: Date internationalization
issue.definition: Date formats are not properly internationalized

notes.note: Corresponds to //date-format// in //locale-convention//. This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: A system displayes all dates as \"Dd/Mm/Yy\", resulting in dates that cannot be understood correctly in much of the world.

issue.name: Measurement internationalization
issue.definition: A product does not provide support for needed measurement formats

notes.note: Corresponds to //measurement-format// in //locale-convention//. This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: An engineering software system developed in France supports only the metric system and when localized for use in the United States does not support U.S. measurement formats, rending it unusable when users print bill of parts sheets to order components from U.S. suppliers.

issue.name: Name internationalization
issue.definition: Forms, databases, or other functional software components do not provide support for needed personal name formats.

notes.note: Corresponds to //name-format// in //locale-convention//. This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: An online registration form asks for “last name” and “first name”, resulting in confusion for users where family names are listed first (e.g., China, Japan, and Hungary) or where users have multiple family names (e.g., Spain, Portugal, Brazil) or only one name (e.g., Indonesia).

issue.name: Number internationalization
issue.definition: Numbers are displayed in the wrong format (e.g, with wrong delimiters)

notes.note: Corresponds to //number-format// in //locale-convention//. This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: An online system displays all numbers with commas to delimit thousands and a full stop (.) to indicate the decimal position. This format is confusing in many locales that use other delimiters or delimit texts using hundreds separators instead of thousands separators.

issue.name: Shortcut key internationalization
issue.definition: Software shortcut keys are set to combinations that do not make sense in all locales and cannot be changed

notes.note: Corresponds to //shortcut-key// in //locale-convention//. This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: CTRL-S is used for saving files and cannot be changed, but some locales customarily use other keyboard shortcuts to save files.

issue.name: Telephone internationalization
issue.definition: The format of telephone numbers is set in forms, databases, or other functional aspects of software and therefore cannot support telephone numbers that do not match this format.

notes.note: Corresponds to //telephone-format// in //locale-convention//. This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: A contact database does not store country codes and fixes all telephone numbers at 10 digits, rejecting any shorter telephone numbers. As a result, it cannot be used outside of a handful of countries that have phone numbers matching these requirements.

issue.name: Time internationalization
issue.definition: Forms, databases, display, or other aspects of software do not support needed time formats

notes.note: Corresponds to //time-format// in //locale-convention//. This is used to mark engineering problems in the source content, not specific problems in the target.

examples.example: A time picker requires users to use AM/PM time even in cases where 24-hour time is the norm.

issue.name: Paper/envelope size
issue.definition: Systems do not support needed paper or envelope sizes

examples.example: A printer driver supports only international A paper sizes, and therefore crops data when printing to US Letter paper.

issue.name: Resource externalization
issue.definition: Translatable resources have not properly been externalized from functional code.

notes.note: Standard practice in writing international code is to put all translatable resource into external resources (such as files containing UI strings). Failure to do so is a major cause of problems or failure in software localization tasks.

examples.example: A legal notice in German uses the informal du instead of the formal Sie.

issue.name: Sequence
issue.definition: Sequences in graphics or text appear in a culture-specific order that does not make sense in other locales.

examples.example: A graphic presents an (implicit) left-to-right ordering of events, but users in the Middle East may follow the steps in reverse order because they expect right-to-left ordering.

issue.name: Text expandability
issue.definition: Insufficient room is left to allow for text expansion

notes.note: This issue corresponds to //truncation-text-expansion// in the Design dimension. This issue is used to identify instances in the source where insufficient room has been left in a document or other item containing text while //truncation-text-expansion// is used for specific cases where text has extended beyond the allowed bounds.

examples.example: Translation specifications state that all localized versions of a service manual must preserve the same pagination as the English source, but no extra room has been left for languages that text more physical space than the source text, such as German (which may be 30% longer than the English source).

issue.name: User interface internationalization
issue.definition: A user interface has not been properly internationalized and so displays problems in localized versions.

examples.example: A user interface was manually aligned and spaced around English-language UI strings and so, when localized, shows strange spacing in the UI.

issue.name: Complexity
issue.definition: Different cultures expect different levels of complexity and presentation of information in user interfaces. If the amount of information is too much or too little for a culture, users will perceive the user interface negatively

notes.note: Solving this problem may involve extensive adaptation of localized versions and may not be solvable by simple internationalization steps.

examples.example: A user interface developed in Sweden has a minimalist aesthetic, but when localized into China, Chinese users expect to find information in the UI that is normally hidden under various options. As a result they may find it frustrating and difficult to use.

issue.name: Fixed dialog/UI size
issue.definition: Dialog boxes or other UI components are fixed in size and cannot adapt to different amounts of content in other languages.

notes.note: Many UI frameworks automatically support dynamic width adjustment. Home-built UIs are particularly prone to this problem.

examples.example: A section for displaying errors in a UI is limited to 200 pixels in width and cannot expand to accommodate longer error messages in another language.

issue.name: Non-dynamic UI
issue.definition: UI components are fixed in position and cannot move to adapt to different locales

notes.note: Many UI frameworks automatically support dynamic adjustment of the position of UI elements. Home-built UIs are particularly prone to this problem.

examples.example: A UI has hard-coded positions in a form and when an address box is expanded to three lines to support addresses in certain locales it then overlaps other UI elements, making them unreadable.

issue.name: Non-reversible UI
issue.definition: A UI cannot be reversed to support bi-directional languages

notes.note: Many UI frameworks automatically support UI adjustment for bi-directional layouts. Home-built UIs are particularly prone to this problem.

examples.example: A web-form is left-aligned with multiple items per line, but when translated to Arabic the items appear in the wrong order because the UI cannot automatically adjust their layout.

issue.name: Other
issue.definition: Used for any issues not adequately covered by the MQM core or extensions. This category should be used only if it is impossible to assign an issue to an existing category with sufficient granularity.

notes.note: This category should be used only for any issue type that cannot be mapped to one of the issue types listed above. If an issue type can be considered a more granular example of an existing type, it should be categorized as that type, possibly with a custom extension if the additional granularity is needed.

examples.example: A quality process checks for errors generated from speech-to-text generated during conference interpretation. Because this error type is highly specific to the specific situation, it is not included in any predefined issue type elsewhere.

issue.name: Style
issue.definition: The text has stylistic problems.

examples.example: The translation of a light-hearted and humorous advertising campaign is in a serious and “heavy” style even though specifications said it should match the style of the source text.

issue.name: Awkward
issue.definition: A text is written with an awkward style

examples.example: A text is written with many embedded clauses and an excessively wordy style. While the meaning can be understood, the text is very awkward and difficult to follow.

issue.name: Company style
issue.definition: The text violates company/organization-specific style guidelines.

examples.example: Company style states that passive sentences may not be used but the text uses passive sentences.

issue.name: Inconsistent style
issue.definition: Style is inconsistent within a text

notes.note: Inconsistent style often emerges when multiple translators have worked on a single text. Because Inconsistent style applies to larger portions of texts, it would generally be assessed with a holistic metric rather than an analytic one.

examples.example: One part of a text is written in a light and “terse” style while other sections are written in a more wordy style.

issue.name: Third-party style
issue.definition: The text violates a third-party style guide

examples.example: Specifications stated that English text was to be formatted according to the Chicago Manual of Style, but the text delivered followed the American Psychological Association style guide.

issue.name: Unidiomatic
issue.definition: The content is grammatical, but not idiomatic

examples.example: The following text appears in an English translation of a German letter: “We thanked him with heart” where “with heart” is an understandable, but non-idiomatic rendering, better stated as “heartily”.

issue.name: Terminology
issue.definition: A term (domain-specific word) is translated with a term other than the one expected for the domain or otherwise specified.

notes.note:
All issues specifically related to use of domain- or organization-specific terminology are included in this issue and its children.
Do not use this issue if a text is simply mistranslated, i.e., if the translation would be a valid translation of the source but simply does not use the particular mandated terminology. For example, if a text translates [river] bank into Spanish as banco (a financial institution) instead of orilla (a river bank), this would be a //mistranslation// because banco would never be a valid term for the concept of a river bank. However, if a termbase specified that orilla should be used and the translation uses ribera instead, this would be a Terminology error because ribera is a valid term for the concept, but not the specified one.

examples.example: A French text translates English e-mail as e-mail but terminology guidelines mandated that courriel be used.
The English musicological term dog is translated (literally) into German as Hund instead of as Schnarre, as specified in a terminology database.

issue.name: Inconsistent with domain
issue.definition: A term is used contrary to general domain expectations

notes.note: This issue is used for cases where no term-base is specified yet common domain conventions about terminology use are violated. If a termbase was specified and that term in question violates it, //termbase// should be used instead, if it is included in the metric (otherwise //terminology// would be used).

examples.example: A financial text is translated using “deduct” instead of “debit”. Although conceptually these could be synonyms in general language, “deduct” violated domain conventions.

issue.name: Inconsistent use of terminology
issue.definition: Terminology is used in an inconsistent manner within the text.

notes.note: This issue and its children are used only to address inconsistent use of terminology. In cases where terminology is incorrect for the domain or termbase //termbase// or //domain-terminology// should be used instead. If further detail is needed about whether the source or target text is responsible for the inconsistent use terminology, use one of the daughter issues.

examples.example: The text refers to a component as the “brake release lever”, “brake disengagement lever”, “manual brake release”, and “manual disengagement release”.

issue.name: Multiple terms for concept in source
issue.definition: A single concept in the source text is expressed with multiple terms for the same concept.

notes.note: Do not use this issue for cases where a single source term is translated in multiple ways in the target language content.

examples.example: A source text inconsistently uses “dog”, “buzzing bridge”, and “buzzer” for the component of a musical instrument.

issue.name: Multiple translations of same term
issue.definition: A single source term is translated in multiple inconsistent ways.

notes.note: Applies to target text only since it refers to cases where one term has multiple translations. As with //term-inconsistency//, //termbase// or one of its children should be used instead if a termbase contains a specified term for a concept and the text does not use that particular term.

examples.example: A German source text uses one term for a component of a vehicle, but the target text uses “brake release lever”, “brake disengagement lever”, “manual brake release”, and “manual disengagement release” for this term in English.

issue.name: Inconsistent with termbase
issue.definition: A term is used inconsistently with a specified termbase

notes.note: For obvious reasons, this issue type applies only in cases where a term is specified in a termbase that was specified for use. If general domain conventions for terminology are violated instead, then //domain-terminology// should be used instead, if it is included in a metric.

examples.example: A termbase specifies that the term USB memory stick shold be used, but the text uses USB flash drive.

issue.name: Company terminology
issue.definition: The text violates company/organization-specific terminology guidelines as specified in a termbase.

notes.note: Should be used when it is necessary to distinguish company-specific terminology issues from more general //termbase// issues.

examples.example: Company-specific terminology guidelines specify that a product be called the “Acme Turbo2000™”, but the text calls it the “Acme Turbo” or the “Turbo200”.

issue.name: Third-party termbase
issue.definition: The text violates terminology guidelines as specified in a termbase from a third-party.

notes.note: Should be used only when it is necessary to distinguish terminology issues related to third-party termbases from more general //termbase// issues.

examples.example: Specifications for translation of a software application specify that UI terms be translated according to the public termbases provided by the developers of the platforms upon which it will be deployed, but certain terms are not translated consistently with these specifications.

issue.name: Verity
issue.definition: The text makes statements that contradict the world of the text

notes.note: Verity issues can apply to the source or target text and often emerge during translation when, for example, a factual statement is true in the source locale but not true in the target locale.

examples.example: The text states that a feature is present on a certain model of automobile when in fact it is not available.

issue.name: Completeness
issue.definition: The text is incomplete

notes.note: //completeness// refers to instances in which needed content is missing in the source language. For cases where material present in the source language is not present in a translation, //omission// should be used instead.

examples.example: A process description leaves out key steps needed to complete the process, resulting in an incomplete description of the process.

issue.name: Incomplete List
issue.definition: A list is missing necessary items

examples.example: A list of items included in a retail package omits a crucial component.

issue.name: Incomplete procedure
issue.definition: A procedure is missing necessary steps.

notes.note: In cases where content is missing from the target text that is present in the source text, //omission// should be used instead

examples.example: A document describing a procedure to restart a diesel generator omits a crucial step that must be completed prior to performing additional steps.

issue.name: End-user suitability
issue.definition: The content is not suitable for use by the end user, excluding problems related to suitability for the target locale.

notes.note: If the issue relates to the applicability of the content to users in a particular locale, //locale-specific-content// should be used instead.

End-user suitability generally applies to issues present in the source text, regardless of the target locale, but may apply in cases where there are distinct differences in audience or purpose between source and target.

examples.example: A text describes a process to repair a device, but following the instructions leads to serious damage to the device and potential injury.
A text assumes that the reader has knowledge of advanced particular physics, but the target audience does not generally have this knowledge.

issue.name: Legal requirements
issue.definition: A text does not meet legal requirements as set forth in the specifications.

notes.note: Generally used in cases where the translation does not meet requirements. Cases in which the source text does not meet legal requirements are generally critical errors that will require rewriting the source text.

examples.example: Specifications stated that FCC regulatory notices be replaced by CE notices rather than translated, but they were translated instead, rendering the text legally problematic for use in Europe.

issue.name: Locale-specific content
issue.definition: Content specific to the source locale does not apply to the intended target locale, audience, or purpose.

notes.note: This issue type is distinguished from //locale-convention// in that this category applies to cases where text corresponds to the conventions of the target locale, but does not apply to the intended audience in the target locale. For example, if the Swedish advertising text mentioned above is properly translated and follows all mechanical locale conventions (e.g., using Swedish kronor instead of euros) but the offer does not apply to Sweden, //cocale-specific-content// should be chosen. If, however, the text applies to the locale, but does not follow locale conventions (e.g., numbers are formatted incorrectly for the locale), //locale-convention// should be used instead.

examples.example: An advertising text translated for Sweden refers to special offers available only in Germany and therefore is misleading.
A manual for a printer sold in Spain describes features that apply only to versions of the printer sold in Japan and thus may confuse purchasers.
